case_title: Qadir, MemberIFTIKHAR HUSSAIN ABBAS-I vs AZAD GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF JAMMU AND KASHMIR
court: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunal
respondant: Azad Government of the State of Jammu and Kashmir

accussed_details.name: Iftikhar Hussain Abbasi
accussed_details.designation: Ex-Deputy Secretary Services and General Administration Department
allegation: Issuance of unauthorized payments from Auqaf Fund without prior approval of the Prime Minister
Issuance of Government Order No. 538-40/76 dated 8-1-1976 sanctioning payment of Rs. 15,000 out of Auqaf Fund.
Issuance of Government Order No. Admin/11054-54/76 dated 17-4-76 sanctioning payment of Rs. 40,000 out of Auqaf Fund.
Failure to obtain concurrence of Finance Department and approval of the Prime Minister before issuance of orders.

complaint_summary: The appellant was accused of issuing unauthorized payments from the Auqaf Fund without obtaining prior approval from the Prime Minister, resulting in alleged financial misconduct. Specific allegations included the issuance of two government orders sanctioning payments totaling Rs. 55,000.
investigation_summary: A Commission of Inquiry was constituted under Section 3 of the Commission of Inquiry Act, 1956, to investigate allegations of misuse and embezzlement of funds. The appellant was summoned but alleged procedural irregularities, including lack of access to evidence and ex parte proceedings.
judgment_summary: The tribunal found that the appellant committed misconduct by issuing payments without prior approval from the Prime Minister, as required under the Rules of Business. However, the tribunal deemed the punishment of removal from service excessive and reduced it, citing mitigating factors such as the appellant's limited experience, urgency of the payments, and recommendations from high-ranking officials.

punishment.tribunal_decision: Punishment reduced to a lesser penalty (specific penalty not detailed in the judgment).

Decision_or_verdict: Appeal accepted with modification of punishment.
legal_arguments: Concurrence of the Finance Department was not required as the Auqaf Fund was not part of government finances.
Approval of the Prime Minister was a technical requirement, but the urgency of the situation justified the appellant's actions.
The inquiry proceedings were ex parte and influenced by the Commission's report, violating procedural fairness.
statutes: Azad Jammu & Kashmir Civil Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1977
Azad Jammu and Kashmir Waqaf Properties Act, 1960
Azad Jammu and Kashmir Waqaf Properties Account Rules, 1961
Azad Jammu and Kashmir Interim Constitution Act, 1974
sections: Rule 4(1) of Azad Jammu & Kashmir Civil Servants (Efficiency and Discipline) Rules, 1977
Section 3 of the Commission of Inquiry Act, 1956
Sections 13 and 14 of Azad Jammu and Kashmir Waqaf Properties Act, 1960
key_issues: Whether the appellant's actions constituted misconduct under the Efficiency and Discipline Rules.
Whether the punishment of removal from service was excessive.
Whether procedural irregularities in the inquiry invalidated the findings.

key_findings.finance_department_concurrence: Not required as the funds were from Auqaf Fund, not Government Finance.
key_findings.prime_minister_approval: Necessary before issuance of orders under Rules of Business, 1975.
key_findings.misconduct_proven: Appellant issued orders without prior approval of Prime Minister.

special_circumstances: Payments were recommended by high-ranking officials.
Urgency of medical treatment for beneficiary.
Appellant had limited experience in secretariat service.

legal_terms.Misconduct: Improper or unlawful behavior by a public servant in the course of their duties.

words_and_phrases.Auqaf Fund: A fund created under the Waqaf Properties Act for religious and charitable purposes.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved allegations of financial misconduct by Iftikhar Hussain Abbasi, an ex-Deputy Secretary, for issuing payments from the Auqaf Fund without prior approval from the Prime Minister. The tribunal found procedural irregularities in the inquiry but upheld the misconduct charge. The punishment was reduced due to mitigating factors, including the appellant's limited experience, urgency of the payments, and recommendations from high-ranking officials.
